question.title: Passing command line arguments to Java via ant build script

node.contents: You mean that from within ant, you call the Java interpreter and want to pass these options along?

astNode.text: You mean that from within ant, you call the Java interpreter and want to pass these options along?

node.contents: @fge, I am hoping I can somehow specify in my build script that I want these parameters to be passed to `java` when project is run.

astNode.text: @fge, I am hoping I can somehow specify in my build script that I want these parameters to be passed to `java` when project is run.

node.contents: I want the command line parameters passed down to java, like java whatever -Dk1=v1 -Dk2=v2.

astNode.text: I want the command line parameters passed down to java, like java whatever -Dk1=v1 -Dk2=v2.

node.contents: I need to access these parameters from Java code with System.getProperty or System.getenv.

astNode.text: I need to access these parameters from Java code with System.getProperty or System.getenv.

node.contents: What do I need to write in my ant build script to make this happen?

astNode.text: What do I need to write in my ant build script to make this happen?

node.contents: Or should I take some other approach altogether?

astNode.text: Or should I take some other approach altogether?

node.contents: Not good in Ant Script but I do something like below :

astNode.text: Not good in Ant Script but I do something like below :

elements.contents: <target name="execute"> <echo> Running MyClass ......... </echo> <java classname="pkg.MyClass" classpathref="libs"> <arg value="val1" /> <!-- command line args --> <arg value="val2" /> <arg value="val3" /> <env key="k1" value="v1" /> <!-- set environmental value --> </java> </target>

units.rawText: <target name="execute"> <echo> Running MyClass ......... </echo> <java classname="pkg.MyClass"classpathref="libs"> <arg value="val1"/> <!-- command line args --> <arg value="val2"/> <arg value="val3"/> <env key="k1"value="v1"/> <!-- set environmental value --> </java> </target>

node.contents: If you are using Eclipse, you will get suggestions in popup under java tag. I got few more like : <sysproperty/>, <syspropertyset></syspropertyset>, <jvmarg/>

astNode.text: If you are using Eclipse, you will get suggestions in popup under java tag. I got few more like : <sysproperty/>, <syspropertyset></syspropertyset>, <jvmarg/>

node.contents: Use the nested <arg> elements in your <java> task:

astNode.text: Use the nested <arg> elements in your <java> task:

node.contents: Is `-Dpsys1=fu` a typo? Should it be `-Dsys1=fu`

astNode.text: Is `-Dpsys1=fu` a typo? Should it be `-Dsys1=fu`

node.contents: I'm not sure exactly how you want to pass these values, but there are several mechanisms:

astNode.text: I'm not sure exactly how you want to pass these values, but there are several mechanisms:

node.contents:
• Use <sysproperty> to pass system properties you need to set:
  • Use <arg> to pass command line arguments to your Java class
  • Use <jvmarg> to pass arguments to your Java command itself
  • If you fork your Java task, you can also set environment variables too. These are ignored if you don't fork the Java task

astNode.text:
• Use <sysproperty> to pass system properties you need to set:
  • Use <arg> to pass command line arguments to your Java class
  • Use <jvmarg> to pass arguments to your Java command itself
  • If you fork your Java task, you can also set environment variables too. These are ignored if you don't fork the Java task

elements.contents: <java classname="com.example.foo.bar" fork="true"> <env key="foo" value="bar"/> <sysproperty key="sys1" value="fu"/> <sysproperty key="sys2" value="barfu"/> <jvmarg value="-Xlingc"/> <arg value="-arg1"/> <arg value="-arg2"/> <arg value="bar"/> </java>

units.rawText: <java classname="com.example.foo.bar"fork="true"> <env key="foo"value="bar"/> <sysproperty key="sys1"value="fu"/> <sysproperty key="sys2"value="barfu"/> <jvmarg value="-Xlingc"/> <arg value="-arg1"/> <arg value="-arg2"/> <arg value="bar"/> </java>
